channel.title: [Tutorial] Convert binary to hexadecimal
channel.description:
Hexadecimal is base-16 notation, and is useful for representing binary numbers.
You can split a byte into two "nybbles", and each nybble contains four bits. One nybble has the possible range of between 0 (0 + 0 + 0 + 0) and 15 (8 + 4 + 2 + 1). This gives each nybble 16 different combinations, making a base-16 system perfect for representing it as it is only one character.
Let's take the binary number 01100111. If we split this into the 128, 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2 and 1 columns, we see that it makes (64 + 32 + 8 + 4 + 2 + 1) which is 111. To represent it as a hexadecimal character, we need to split it into two nybbles.
We now have 0110 and 0111. To start with, we take the rightmost nybble, 0111. We split it into the 8 4 2 1 columns and this nybble has a value of 7. In hexadecimal, 7 is represented as [b]7[/b]. We then take the next rightmost nybble, 0110, and split it the same way (into 8 4 2 1). This nybble has a value of 6, which is represented in Hexadecimal as 6. Therefore, 01100111 can be represented as 67 in hexadecimal.
Let's take a larger number, 01011111. This has a denary (decimal) value of 95. Let's split it into nybbles and get converting: 0101 and 1111. 1111 has a denary value of 15 when split into the 8 4 2 1 columns, which is represented in hexadecimal as F. 0101 has a denary value of 5 when split into the 8 4 2 1 columns and is represented in hexadecimal as 5. This means that 01011111 has a hexadecimal representation of 5F.
This is used more in theoretical computing rather than actual computing, but it can make code a bit cleaner if you are working with very long, constant integer values.

item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Fat Cookies:

This same technique can be used to convert between any number system which is a multiple of base 2, for example binary (base 2) -> octal (base 8) just involves splitting the binary string into groups of 3 bits (2^3 = 8). binary -> base64 could be converted by grouping the binary bits into groups of 6 (2^6 = 64). Can be adapted to conversions not involving binary such as octal (8) -> base64 (64) - which is just done by grouping two octal digits together.

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:9, topic:538906”]Hexadecimal or any base number system is not limited to computers. (Although that is their primary usage). Saying no, I would like to clarify I am not being specific about Hexadecimal but rather base number systems in general are not limited just computers. I believe it was hexadecimal that was used during the Vietnam War to coordinate bombings on a grid in relation to the square miles of that country. That was all done by hand. Besides military use of these numerical systems…

I would like to point out that this is the problem with anyone interested in programming. How can you possibly use something without knowing what is going on? In this case people not knowing what hexadecimal is and just doing the “Integer.toHexString(binayNumber)”. Yea sure, it’s a great tool… but you really need to learn what is going on or you’re not going to get anywhere. There are the people that use to available API and there are others who well… make them and that’s the people who are the real “programmers”.

TLDR : It shouldn’t be theoretical. You should know it, if you’re serious about computing.[/quote]
